00028 //
00029 // Type of model
00030 //
00031 typedef enum vmiModelTypeE {
00032     VMI_PROCESSOR_MODEL = 0,
00033     VMI_INTERCEPT_LIBRARY,
00034     VMI_MMC_MODEL,
00035     VMI_MODULE,
00036     VMI_PERIPHERAL,           // this is a place keeper
00037     VMI_RESERVED_2_MODEL,
00038     VMI_RESERVED_3_MODEL
00039 } vmiModelType;

00041 //
00042 // This type is used to define attributes of an SMP processor in the processor
00043 // constructor (see macro VMI_CONSTRUCTOR_FN)
00044 //
00045 typedef struct vmiSMPContextS {
00046     Bool  isContainer;  // whether this processor is a container
00047     Uns32 numChildren;  // if a container, the initial number of children
00048     Uns32 numSubSlices; // if a container, the number of subslices
00049     Uns32 index;        // index number in schedule list
00050 } vmiSMPContext, *vmiSMPContextP;
00051 
00052 //
00053 // This type is returned by vmirtGetSMPCpuType()
00054 //
00055 typedef enum vmiSMPCpuTypeE {
00056     SMP_TYPE_CONTAINER = 0x0,   // Container Processor
00057     SMP_TYPE_LEAF      = 0x1,   // Leaf processor
00058     SMP_TYPE_GROUP     = 0x2,   // Part of an SMP simulation group
00059 
00060     // simple leaf processor (not a member of an SMP simulation group)
00061     SMP_SIMPLE_LEAF = SMP_TYPE_LEAF,
00062     // leaf processor that is a member of an SMP simulation group
00063     SMP_GROUP_LEAF  = SMP_TYPE_LEAF     | SMP_TYPE_GROUP,
00064     // simple container processor
00065     SMP_CONTAINER   = SMP_TYPE_CONTAINER,
00066     // container processor that contains a group of SMP_GROUP_LEAF processors
00067     SMP_GROUP       = SMP_TYPE_CONTAINER | SMP_TYPE_GROUP,
00068 } vmiSMPCpuType;
00069 
00070 // Is a processor of vmiSMPCpuType _T a leaf processor
00071 #define SMP_IS_LEAF(_T) ((_T) & SMP_TYPE_LEAF)
00072 
00073 // Is a processor of vmiSMPCpuType _T an SMP group processor
00074 #define SMP_IS_GROUP(_T) ((_T) & SMP_TYPE_GROUP)
00075 
00076 //
00077 // Use to describe activation and deactivation of processor at context switch
00078 //
00079 typedef enum vmiIASRunStateE {
00080     RS_RUN,         // processor about to be run
00081     RS_SUSPEND      // processor has just been suspended
00082 } vmiIASRunState;
00083 
00084 //
00085 // Used to describe phase when checkpoint/restore is in progress
00086 //
00087 typedef enum vmiSaveRestorePhaseE {
00088     SRT_BEGIN,      // start save/restore for a processor (or SMP container)
00089     SRT_BEGIN_CORE, // start save/restore for a single SMP core
00090     SRT_END_CORE,   // end save/restore for a single SMP core
00091     SRT_END,        // end save/restore for a processor (or SMP container)
00092 } vmiSaveRestorePhase;
00093 
00094 //
00095 // Used to describe status of save/restore operation
00096 //
00097 typedef enum vmiSaveRestoreStatusE {
00098     SRS_ERROR,      // error in save/restore restore
00099     SRS_OK,         // successful operation
00100     SRS_END_LIST    // end of list (vmirtSaveElement/vmirtRestoreElement only)
00101 } vmiSaveRestoreStatus;

00103 //
00104 // Used to control disassembly
00105 //
00106 typedef enum vmiDisassAttrsE {
00107     DSA_NORMAL   = 0x00000000,  // normal disassembly
00108     DSA_UNCOOKED = 0x00000001,  // model-specific uncooked format
00109     DSA_BASE     = 0x00000002,  // use base model disassembly (not intercept)
00110     DSA_MODEL    = 0x80000000,  // model-specific mask
00111 } vmiDisassAttrs;
00112 
00113 //
00114 // This bitmask is used with vmirtRead*/vmirtWrite* functions to describe the
00115 // access characteristics. Valid values are:
00116 //
00117 // MEM_AA_FALSE: indicates that the access is an artifact read/write, which
00118 // should not update processor state.
00119 //
00120 // MEM_AA_TRUE: indicates that the access is a true read/write which may update
00121 // processor state (for example, it may initiate entry to an exception handler
00122 // to handle an illegal address).
00123 //
00124 // MEM_AA_FETCH: indicates that the access is an artifact fetch, which should
00125 // not update processor state.
00126 //
00127 // MEM_AA_TRUE|MEM_AA_FETCH: indicates that the access is a true fetch which may
00128 // update processor state (for example, it may initiate entry to an exception
00129 // handler to handle an illegal address).
00130 //
00131 typedef enum memAccessAttrsE {
00132     MEM_AA_FALSE = 0x0, // this is an artifact access
00133     MEM_AA_TRUE  = 0x1, // this is a true processor access
00134     MEM_AA_FETCH = 0x2, // this access is a fetch
00135 } memAccessAttrs;
00136 
00137 //
00138 // Is the memory access a true access?
00139 //
00140 #define MEM_AA_IS_TRUE_ACCESS(_MA) (((_MA) & MEM_AA_TRUE) && True)
00141 
00142 //
00143 // Is the memory access an artifact access?
00144 //
00145 #define MEM_AA_IS_ARTIFACT_ACCESS(_MA) (!MEM_AA_IS_TRUE_ACCESS(_MA))
00146 
00147 //
00148 // Is the memory access a fetch?
00149 //
00150 #define MEM_AA_IS_FETCH(_MA) (((_MA) & MEM_AA_FETCH) && True)
00151 
00152 //
00153 // Deprecated memAccessAttrs value
00154 //
00155 #define MEM_AA_IGNORE_PRIV MEM_AA_TRUE
00156 
00157 //
00158 // Macros defining read and write functions used for callback-mapped memory (see
00159 // vmirtMapCallbacks). Note that argument 'isFetch' is deprecated and will be
00160 // removed in future; please use MEM_AA_IS_FETCH(attrs) instead.
00161 //
00162 #define VMI_MEM_READ_FN(_NAME) void _NAME( \
00163     vmiProcessorP  processor,   \
00164     Addr           address,     \
00165     Uns32          bytes,       \
00166     void          *value,       \
00167     void          *userData,    \
00168     Addr           VA,          \
00169     Bool           isFetch,     \
00170     memAccessAttrs attrs        \
00171 )
00172 #define VMI_MEM_WRITE_FN(_NAME) void _NAME( \
00173     vmiProcessorP  processor,   \
00174     Addr           address,     \
00175     Uns32          bytes,       \
00176     const void    *value,       \
00177     void          *userData,    \
00178     Addr           VA,          \
00179     memAccessAttrs attrs        \
00180 )
00181 
00182 //
00183 // Prototypes for read and write functions used for callback-mapped memory (see
00184 // vmirtMapCallbacks)
00185 //
00186 typedef VMI_MEM_READ_FN((*vmiMemReadFn));
00187 typedef VMI_MEM_WRITE_FN((*vmiMemWriteFn));
00188 
00189 //
00190 // Macro defining read/write notification callback function (see
00191 // vmirtAddReadCallback, vmirtRemoveReadCallback, vmirtAddWriteCallback and
00192 // vmirtRemoveWriteCallback)
00193 //
00194 #define VMI_MEM_WATCH_FN(_NAME) void _NAME( \
00195     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
00196     Addr          address,      \
00197     Uns32         bytes,        \
00198     const void   *value,        \
00199     void         *userData,     \
00200     Addr          VA            \
00201 )
00202 
00203 //
00204 // Prototype for read/write notification callback function (see
00205 // vmirtAddReadCallback, vmirtRemoveReadCallback, vmirtAddWriteCallback and
00206 // vmirtRemoveWriteCallback)
00207 //
00208 typedef VMI_MEM_WATCH_FN((*vmiMemWatchFn));

00210 //
00211 // Endianness for memory accesses
00212 //
00213 typedef enum memEndianE {
00214     MEM_ENDIAN_LITTLE = 0,  // little endian
00215     MEM_ENDIAN_BIG    = 1   // big endian
00216 } memEndian;
00217 
00218 //
00219 // Access constraints for memory accesses (bitfield)
00220 //
00221 typedef enum memConstraintE {
00222     MEM_CONSTRAINT_NONE      = 0x0, // no constraint
00223     MEM_CONSTRAINT_ALIGNED   = 0x1, // access must not be misaligned
00224     MEM_CONSTRAINT_NO_DEVICE = 0x2  // access must not be to device memory
00225                                     // (with privilege MEM_PRIV_DEVICE)
00226 } memConstraint;
00227 
00228 //
00229 // Load/store mask action
00230 //
00231 typedef enum memLSMActionE {
00232     MEM_LSM_NONE = 0,   // no action
00233     MEM_LSM_0    = 1,   // fill masked section of the address with 0
00234     MEM_LSM_1    = 2    // fill masked section of the address with 1
00235 } memLSMAction;
00236 
00237 //
00238 // Structure for management of MRU state on memory access
00239 //
00240 typedef struct memMRUSetS {
00241     const Uns32 *nextState;     // LUT giving next state from current state
00242     Uns32       *currentState;  // reference to current state
00243 } memMRUSet;
00244 
00245 //
00246 // This defines memory that should use physically-mapped code dictionaries
00247 //
00248 #define MEM_MAP_PHYSICAL ((memMRUSetP)-1)
00249

00251 // This defines endianness of the host
00252 //
00253 #define MEM_ENDIAN_NATIVE MEM_ENDIAN_LITTLE

00256 // Memory type

00258 typedef enum memTypeE {
00259     MEM_ROM =1,         // read only memory
00260     MEM_RAM =2,         // read/write memory
00261 } memType;
00262 
00263 //
00264 // Memory access privilege (bitmask)
00265 //
00266 typedef enum memPrivE {
00267 
00268     // access permission options
00269     MEM_PRIV_NONE   = 0x00, // no access permitted
00270     MEM_PRIV_R      = 0x01, // read permitted
00271     MEM_PRIV_W      = 0x02, // write permitted
00272     MEM_PRIV_RW     = 0x03, // read & write permitted
00273     MEM_PRIV_X      = 0x04, // execute permitted
00274     MEM_PRIV_RX     = 0x05, // read & execute permitted
00275     MEM_PRIV_WX     = 0x06, // write & execute permitted
00276     MEM_PRIV_RWX    = 0x07, // read, write & execute permitted
00277 
00278     // other access constraints
00279     MEM_PRIV_ALIGN  = 0x08, // alignment checks always enabled
00280     MEM_PRIV_DEVICE = 0x10, // device region with restricted access
00281 
00282 } memPriv;
00283 
00284 //
00285 // Enumeration describing how addresses in a memory range are mapped
00286 //
00287 typedef enum memMappedE {
00288     MEM_MAP_NONE = 0,   // no addresses in the range mapped
00289     MEM_MAP_PART = 1,   // some addresses in the range mapped
00290     MEM_MAP_FULL = 2,   // all addresses in the range mapped
00291 } memMapped;
00292 
00293 //
00294 // Enumeration describing whether a simulated address is ASID-mapped and, if so,
00295 // whether that mapping is active in the simulator
00296 //
00297 typedef enum memMappedASIDE {
00298     ASID_MAP_NONE,      // address not ASID-mapped
00299     ASID_MAP_INACTIVE,  // address ASID-mapped but not active
00300     ASID_MAP_ACTIVE     // address ASID-mapped and active
00301 } memMappedASID;
00302 
00303 //
00304 // How privilege mask is to be applied
00305 //
00306 typedef enum memPrivActionE {
00307     MEM_PRIV_SET,       // set privileges using mask
00308     MEM_PRIV_ADD,       // add privileges using mask
00309     MEM_PRIV_SUB        // remove privileges using mask
00310 } memPrivAction;
00311 
00312 //
00313 // Macro to construct suitable return value for read and write alignment snap
00314 // handlers when address snapping and/or value rotation are required. Parameter
00315 // _SNAP indicates address alignment in bytes (typically 1, 2, 4 or 8) and
00316 // parameter _ROTATE indicates rotation in bits.
00317 //
00318 #define MEM_SNAP(_SNAP, _ROTATE) (((Uns8)(_SNAP)) | ((_ROTATE)<<8))
00319 
00320 //
00321 // Enumeration of unary operation types
00322 //
00323 typedef enum {
00324                     // MOVE OPERATIONS
00325     vmi_MOV,        // d <- a
00326     vmi_SWP,        // d <- byteswap(a)
00327 
00328                     // ARITHMETIC OPERATIONS
00329     vmi_NEG,        // d <- -a
00330     vmi_ABS,        // d <- (a<0) ? -a : a
00331 
00332                     // SATURATED ARITHMETIC OPERATIONS
00333     vmi_NEGSQ,      // d <- saturate_signed(-a)
00334     vmi_ABSSQ,      // d <- (a<0) ? saturate_signed(-a) : a
00335 
00336                     // BITWISE OPERATIONS
00337     vmi_NOT,        // d <- ~a
00338 
00339                     // MISCELLANEOUS OPERATIONS
00340     vmi_CLZ,        // d <- count_leading_zeros(a)
00341     vmi_CLO,        // d <- count_leading_ones(a)
00342     vmi_CTZ,        // d <- count_trailing_zeros(a)
00343     vmi_CTO,        // d <- count_trailing_ones(a)
00344     vmi_BSFZ,       // d <- least_significant_zero_index(a)
00345     vmi_BSFO,       // d <- least_significant_one_index(a)
00346     vmi_BSRZ,       // d <- most_significant_zero_index(a)
00347     vmi_BSRO,       // d <- most_significant_one_index(a)
00348 
00349     vmi_UNOP_LAST   // KEEP LAST
00350 
00351 } vmiUnop;
00352 
00353 //
00354 // Enumeration of binary integral operation types
00355 //
00356 typedef enum {
00357                     // ARITHMETIC OPERATIONS
00358     vmi_ADD,        // d <- a + b
00359     vmi_ADC,        // d <- a + b + C
00360     vmi_SUB,        // d <- a - b
00361     vmi_SBB,        // d <- a - b - C
00362     vmi_RSBB,       // d <- b - a - C
00363     vmi_RSUB,       // d <- b - a
00364     vmi_IMUL,       // d <- a * b (signed)
00365     vmi_MUL,        // d <- a * b (unsigned)
00366     vmi_IDIV,       // d <- a / b (signed)
00367     vmi_DIV,        // d <- a / b (unsigned)
00368     vmi_IREM,       // d <- a % b (signed)
00369     vmi_REM,        // d <- a % b (unsigned)
00370     vmi_CMP,        // a - b
00371 
00372                     // SATURATED ARITHMETIC OPERATIONS
00373     vmi_ADDSQ,      // d <- saturate_signed(a + b)
00374     vmi_SUBSQ,      // d <- saturate_signed(a - b)
00375     vmi_RSUBSQ,     // d <- saturate_signed(b - a)
00376     vmi_ADDUQ,      // d <- saturate_unsigned(a + b)
00377     vmi_SUBUQ,      // d <- saturate_unsigned(a - b)
00378     vmi_RSUBUQ,     // d <- saturate_unsigned(b - a)
00379 
00380                     // HALVING ARITHMETIC OPERATIONS
00381     vmi_ADDSH,      // d <- ((signed)(a + b)) / 2
00382     vmi_SUBSH,      // d <- ((signed)(a - b)) / 2
00383     vmi_RSUBSH,     // d <- ((signed)(b - a)) / 2
00384     vmi_ADDUH,      // d <- ((unsigned)(a + b)) / 2
00385     vmi_SUBUH,      // d <- ((unsigned)(a - b)) / 2
00386     vmi_RSUBUH,     // d <- ((unsigned)(b - a)) / 2
00387     vmi_ADDSHR,     // d <- round(((signed)(a + b)) / 2)
00388     vmi_SUBSHR,     // d <- round(((signed)(a - b)) / 2)
00389     vmi_RSUBSHR,    // d <- round(((signed)(b - a)) / 2)
00390     vmi_ADDUHR,     // d <- round(((unsigned)(a + b)) / 2)
00391     vmi_SUBUHR,     // d <- round(((unsigned)(a - b)) / 2)
00392     vmi_RSUBUHR,    // d <- round(((unsigned)(b - a)) / 2)
00393 
00394                     // BITWISE OPERATIONS
00395     vmi_OR,         // d <- a | b
00396     vmi_AND,        // d <- a & b
00397     vmi_XOR,        // d <- a ^ b
00398     vmi_ORN,        // d <- a | ~b
00399     vmi_ANDN,       // d <- a & ~b
00400     vmi_XORN,       // d <- a ^ ~b
00401     vmi_NOR,        // d <- ~(a | b)
00402     vmi_NAND,       // d <- ~(a & b)
00403     vmi_XNOR,       // d <- ~(a ^ b)
00404 
00405                     // SHIFT/ROTATE OPERATIONS
00406     vmi_ROL,        // d <- a << b | a >> <bits>-b
00407     vmi_ROR,        // d <- a >> b | a << <bits>-b
00408     vmi_RCL,        // (d,c) <- (a,c) << b | (a,c) >> <bits>-b
00409     vmi_RCR,        // (d,c) <- (a,c) >> b | (a,c) << <bits>-b
00410     vmi_SHL,        // d <- a << b
00411     vmi_SHR,        // d <- (unsigned)a >> b
00412     vmi_SAR,        // d <- (signed)a >> b
00413 
00414                     // SATURATED SHIFT OPERATIONS
00415     vmi_SHLSQ,      // d <- saturate_signed(a << b)
00416     vmi_SHLUQ,      // d <- saturate_unsigned(a << b)
00417 
00418                     // ROUNDING SHIFT OPERATIONS
00419     vmi_SHRR,       // d <- round((unsigned)a >> b)
00420     vmi_SARR,       // d <- round((signed)a >> b)
00421 
00422     vmi_BINOP_LAST  // KEEP LAST
00423 
00424 } vmiBinop;
00425 
00426 //
00427 // Enumeration of condition types
00428 //
00429 typedef enum {
00430     vmi_COND_O   = 0,   // overflow                         (OF==1)
00431     vmi_COND_NO  = 1,   // no overflow                      (OF==0)
00432     vmi_COND_B   = 2,   // below (unsigned)                 (CF==1)
00433     vmi_COND_C   = 2,   // carry (alias of below)           (CF==1)
00434     vmi_COND_NB  = 3,   // not below (unsigned)             (CF==0)
00435     vmi_COND_NC  = 3,   // no carry (alias of not below)    (CF==0)
00436     vmi_COND_Z   = 4,   // zero                             (ZF==1)
00437     vmi_COND_EQ  = 4,   // equal (alias of zero)            (ZF==1)
00438     vmi_COND_NZ  = 5,   // not zero                         (ZF==0)
00439     vmi_COND_NE  = 5,   // not equal (alias of not zero)    (ZF==0)
00440     vmi_COND_BE  = 6,   // below or equal (unsigned)        (CF==1 || ZF==1)
00441     vmi_COND_NBE = 7,   // not below or equal (unsigned)    (CF==0 && ZF==0)
00442     vmi_COND_S   = 8,   // negative                         (SF==1)
00443     vmi_COND_NS  = 9,   // not negative                     (SF==0)
00444     vmi_COND_P   = 10,  // parity even                      (PF==1)
00445     vmi_COND_NP  = 11,  // not parity even                  (PF==0)
00446     vmi_COND_L   = 12,  // less (signed)                    (SF!=OF)
00447     vmi_COND_NL  = 13,  // not less (signed)                (SF==OF)
00448     vmi_COND_LE  = 14,  // less or equal (signed)           (ZF==1 || SF!=OF)
00449     vmi_COND_NLE = 15   // not less or equal (signed)       (ZF==0 && SF==OF)
00450 } vmiCondition;
00451 
00452 //
00453 // Hint for jump types (call/return pairing and relative jump indication)
00454 //
00455 typedef enum {
00456 
00457     vmi_JH_NONE      = 0x00,                        // no jump hint
00458 
00459     vmi_JH_CALL      = 0x01,                        // call
00460     vmi_JH_RETURN    = 0x02,                        // return
00461     vmi_JH_INT       = 0x04,                        // interrupt
00462     vmi_JH_CALLINT   = vmi_JH_INT|vmi_JH_CALL,      // interrupt call
00463     vmi_JH_RETURNINT = vmi_JH_INT|vmi_JH_RETURN,    // interrupt return
00464 
00465     vmi_JH_RELATIVE  = 0x08                         // target is relative
00466 
00467 } vmiJumpHint;
00468 
00469 //
00470 // Enumeration of unary floating point operation types
00471 //
00472 typedef enum {
00473                     // BASIC ARITHMETIC OPERATIONS
00474     vmi_FMOV,       // d <- a
00475     vmi_FABS,       // d <- abs(a), signalling
00476     vmi_FQABS,      // d <- abs(a), IEEE 754-2008 (clear sign bit only)
00477     vmi_FNEG,       // d <- -a,     signalling
00478     vmi_FQNEG,      // d <- -a,     IEEE 754-2008 (toggle sign bit only)
00479     vmi_FRECIP,     // d <- 1/a
00480     vmi_FSQRT,      // d <- sqrt(a)
00481     vmi_FRSQRT,     // d <- 1/sqrt(a)
00482 
00483                     // ROUNDING OPERATIONS
00484     vmi_FCEIL,      // d <- roundTowardsPositiveInfinity(a)
00485     vmi_FFLOOR,     // d <- roundTowardsNegativeInfinity(a)
00486     vmi_FNEAREST,   // d <- roundToNearest(a)
00487     vmi_FTRUNC,     // d <- roundTowardsZero(a)
00488     vmi_FROUNDC,    // d <- roundUsingCurrentRoundingMode(a)
00489     vmi_FAWAY,      // d <- roundToNearestTiesToAway(a)
00490 
00491                     // TRIGONOMETRIC OPERATIONS
00492     vmi_FSIN,       // d <- sin(a)
00493     vmi_FCOS,       // d <- cos(a)
00494 
00495                     // LOGARITHMIC OPERATIONS
00496     vmi_FLOG2,      // d <- log2(a)
00497 
00498                     // USER-DEFINED OPERATIONS
00499     vmi_FUNUD,      // (implemented with result handler functions)
00500 
00501     vmi_FUNOP_LAST  // KEEP LAST
00502 
00503 } vmiFUnop;
00504 
00505 //
00506 // Enumeration of binary floating point operation types
00507 //
00508 typedef enum {
00509                     // BASIC ARITHMETIC OPERATIONS
00510     vmi_FADD,       // d <- a + b
00511     vmi_FSUB,       // d <- a - b
00512     vmi_FMUL,       // d <- a * b
00513     vmi_FDIV,       // d <- a / b
00514 
00515                     // MIN/MAX OPERATIONS
00516     vmi_FMIN,       // d <- min(a, b)
00517     vmi_FMAX,       // d <- max(a, b)
00518 
00519                     // SCALE OPERATIONS
00520     vmi_FSCALEF,    // d <- a * 2^b (floating point b)
00521     vmi_FSCALEI,    // d <- a * 2^b (integer b)
00522 
00523                     // QUIET COMPARISON OPERATIONS
00524     vmi_FQCMPEQ,    // d <-  (a == b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00525     vmi_FQCMPNEQ,   // d <- !(a == b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00526     vmi_FQCMPLT,    // d <-  (a <  b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00527     vmi_FQCMPNLT,   // d <- !(a <  b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00528     vmi_FQCMPLE,    // d <-  (a <= b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00529     vmi_FQCMPNLE,   // d <- !(a <= b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00530     vmi_FQCMPGT,    // d <-  (a >  b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00531     vmi_FQCMPNGT,   // d <- !(a >  b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00532     vmi_FQCMPGE,    // d <-  (a >= b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00533     vmi_FQCMPNGE,   // d <- !(a >= b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00534     vmi_FQCMPOR,    // d <-  ordered(a,b) ? all_ones : all_zeros
00535     vmi_FQCMPNOR,   // d <- !ordered(a,b) ? all_ones : all_zeros
00536 
00537                     // SIGNALLING COMPARISON OPERATIONS
00538     vmi_FSCMPEQ,    // d <-  (a == b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00539     vmi_FSCMPNEQ,   // d <- !(a == b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00540     vmi_FSCMPLT,    // d <-  (a <  b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00541     vmi_FSCMPNLT,   // d <- !(a <  b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00542     vmi_FSCMPLE,    // d <-  (a <= b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00543     vmi_FSCMPNLE,   // d <- !(a <= b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00544     vmi_FSCMPGT,    // d <-  (a >  b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00545     vmi_FSCMPNGT,   // d <- !(a >  b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00546     vmi_FSCMPGE,    // d <-  (a >= b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00547     vmi_FSCMPNGE,   // d <- !(a >= b)     ? all_ones : all_zeros
00548     vmi_FSCMPOR,    // d <-  ordered(a,b) ? all_ones : all_zeros
00549     vmi_FSCMPNOR,   // d <- !ordered(a,b) ? all_ones : all_zeros
00550 
00551                     // USER-DEFINED OPERATIONS
00552     vmi_FBINUD,     // (implemented with result handler functions)
00553 
00554     vmi_FBINOP_LAST // KEEP LAST
00555 
00556 } vmiFBinop;
00557 
00558 //
00559 // Enumeration of ternary floating point operation types
00560 //
00561 typedef enum {
00562                     // UNFUSED OPERATION            FUSED OPERATION
00563     vmi_FMADD,      // d <- (a * b) + c             d <- ( a * b) + c
00564     vmi_FMSUB,      // d <- (a * b) - c             d <- ( a * b) - c
00565     vmi_FNMADD,     // d <- -((a * b) + c)          d <- (-a * b) + c
00566     vmi_FNMSUB,     // d <- -((a * b) - c)          d <- (-a * b) - c
00567     vmi_FMSUBR,     // d <- c - (a * b)             d <- (-a * b) + c
00568     vmi_FMADDH,     // d <- ((a * b) + c) / 2.0     d <- (( a * b) + c) / 2.0
00569     vmi_FMSUBH,     // d <- ((a * b) - c) / 2.0     d <- (( a * b) - c) / 2.0
00570     vmi_FMSUBRH,    // d <- (c - (a * b)) / 2.0     d <- ((-a * b) + c) / 2.0
00571 
00572     vmi_FTERNOP_LAST// KEEP LAST
00573 
00574 } vmiFTernop;
00575 
00576 //
00577 // Enumeration of floating point relations (bitmask)
00578 //
00579 typedef enum {
00580     vmi_FPRL_UNORDERED = 0x1,   // unordered
00581     vmi_FPRL_EQUAL     = 0x2,   // equal
00582     vmi_FPRL_LESS      = 0x4,   // less than
00583     vmi_FPRL_GREATER   = 0x8    // greater than
00584 } vmiFPRelation;
00585 
00586 //
00587 // These values are used to define types for floating point operations
00588 //
00589 #define VMI_FT_MASK     0xf000
00590 #define VMI_FT_IEEE_754 0x1000
00591 #define VMI_FT_X87      0x2000
00592 #define VMI_FT_INT      0x3000
00593 #define VMI_FT_UNS      0x4000
00594 
00595 //
00596 // Enumeration of floating point argument types
00597 //
00598 typedef enum {
00599 
00600     // these values specify that evaluation should be performed using IEEE 754
00601     // semantics (intermediates are the same type)
00602     vmi_FT_32_IEEE_754 = 32 | VMI_FT_IEEE_754,  // 32-bit floating point
00603     vmi_FT_64_IEEE_754 = 64 | VMI_FT_IEEE_754,  // 64-bit floating point
00604 
00605     // these values specify that evaluation should be performed using Intel x87
00606     // semantics (intermediates are promoted to 80-bit long double format)
00607     vmi_FT_32_X87      = 32 | VMI_FT_X87,       // 32-bit floating point
00608     vmi_FT_64_X87      = 64 | VMI_FT_X87,       // 64-bit floating point
00609     vmi_FT_80_X87      = 80 | VMI_FT_X87,       // 80-bit floating point
00610 
00611     // these values are valid in conversion operations only
00612     vmi_FT_16_INT      = 16 | VMI_FT_INT,       // 16-bit signed integer
00613     vmi_FT_32_INT      = 32 | VMI_FT_INT,       // 32-bit signed integer
00614     vmi_FT_64_INT      = 64 | VMI_FT_INT,       // 64-bit signed integer
00615     vmi_FT_16_UNS      = 16 | VMI_FT_UNS,       // 16-bit unsigned integer
00616     vmi_FT_32_UNS      = 32 | VMI_FT_UNS,       // 32-bit unsigned integer
00617     vmi_FT_64_UNS      = 64 | VMI_FT_UNS,       // 64-bit unsigned integer
00618 
00619 } vmiFType;
00620 
00621 //
00622 // Given a floating point type, return the size of that in bits
00623 //
00624 #define VMI_FTYPE_BITS(_T) ((_T) & ~VMI_FT_MASK)
00625 
00626 //
00627 // Predicates for floating point type extraction
00628 //
00629 #define VMI_FTYPE_IS_IEEE_754(_T)   (((_T) & VMI_FT_MASK) == VMI_FT_IEEE_754)
00630 #define VMI_FTYPE_IS_X87(_T)        (((_T) & VMI_FT_MASK) == VMI_FT_X87)
00631 #define VMI_FTYPE_IS_INT(_T)        (((_T) & VMI_FT_MASK) == VMI_FT_INT)
00632 #define VMI_FTYPE_IS_UNS(_T)        (((_T) & VMI_FT_MASK) == VMI_FT_UNS)
00633 
00634 //
00635 // Enumeration describing floating point rounding control
00636 //
00637 typedef enum {
00638 
00639     // these values are valid in both conversion functions and in the rounding
00640     // control field of vmiFPControlWord, below
00641     vmi_FPR_NEAREST = 0,    // round towards nearest (even)
00642     vmi_FPR_NEG_INF = 1,    // round towards negative infinity
00643     vmi_FPR_POS_INF = 2,    // round towards positive infinity
00644     vmi_FPR_ZERO    = 3,    // round towards zero
00645 
00646     // these values are valid in conversion functions only
00647     vmi_FPR_CURRENT = 4,    // use currently-active rounding control
00648     vmi_FPR_AWAY    = 5,    // round towards nearest, tie away
00649     vmi_FPR_ODD     = 6     // round to odd (Von Neumann rounding)
00650 
00651 } vmiFPRC;
00652 
00653 //
00654 // Structure defining floating point control word - used with
00655 // vmirtGetFPControlWord and vmirtSetFPControlWord
00656 //
00657 typedef struct vmiFPControlWordS {
00658 
00659                         // INTERRUPT MASKS
00660     Uns32   IM  : 1;    // invalid operation mask
00661     Uns32   DM  : 1;    // denormal mask
00662     Uns32   ZM  : 1;    // divide-by-zero mask
00663     Uns32   OM  : 1;    // overflow mask
00664     Uns32   UM  : 1;    // underflow mask
00665     Uns32   PM  : 1;    // precision mask
00666 
00667                         // ROUNDING AND PRECISION
00668     Uns32   RC  : 2;    // rounding control
00669     Uns32   FZ  : 1;    // flush to zero
00670     Uns32   DAZ : 1;    // denormals are zeros flag
00671 
00672 } vmiFPControlWord;
00673 
00674 //
00675 // Structure defining floating point flags for the last floating point operation
00676 //
00677 typedef union vmiFPFlagsU {
00678     Uns8 bits;      // all flags
00679     struct {
00680         Uns32 I  : 1;   // invalid operation flag
00681         Uns32 D  : 1;   // denormal flag
00682         Uns32 Z  : 1;   // divide-by-zero flag
00683         Uns32 O  : 1;   // overflow flag
00684         Uns32 U  : 1;   // underflow flag
00685         Uns32 P  : 1;   // precision flag
00686         Uns32 R1 : 1;   // (reserved for internal use)
00687         Uns32 R2 : 1;   // (reserved for internal use)
00688     } f;
00689 } vmiFPFlags;
00690 
00691 //
00692 // This can be used to decompose an Flt16 value
00693 //
00694 typedef struct Flt16PartsS {
00695     Uns32 fraction : 10;
00696     Uns32 exponent :  5;
00697     Bool  sign     :  1;
00698 } Flt16Parts;
00699 
00700 //
00701 // This can be used to decompose an Flt32 value
00702 //
00703 typedef struct Flt32PartsS {
00704     Uns32 fraction : 23;
00705     Uns32 exponent :  8;
00706     Bool  sign     :  1;
00707 } Flt32Parts;
00708 
00709 //
00710 // This can be used to decompose an Flt64 value
00711 //
00712 typedef struct Flt64PartsS {
00713     Uns64 fraction : 52;
00714     Uns32 exponent : 11;
00715     Bool  sign     :  1;
00716 } Flt64Parts;
00717 
00718 //
00719 // This can be used to decompose an Flt80 value
00720 //
00721 typedef struct Flt80PartsS {
00722     Uns64 fraction : 64;
00723     Uns32 exponent : 15;
00724     Bool  sign     :  1;
00725 } Flt80Parts;

00727 //
00728 // Structure used to hold argument values for floating point result handlers
00729 //
00730 #define VMI_FP_80_BYTES 10
00731 typedef struct vmiFPArgS {
00732     vmiFType type;
00733     union {
00734         // use these for 16-bit types
00735         Uns16      u16;
00736         Int16      i16;
00737         Flt16Parts f16Parts;
00738         // use these for 32-bit types
00739         Uns32      u32;
00740         Int32      i32;
00741         Flt32      f32;
00742         Flt32Parts f32Parts;
00743         // use these for 64-bit types
00744         Uns64      u64;
00745         Int64      i64;
00746         Flt64      f64;
00747         Flt64Parts f64Parts;
00748         // use these for 80-bit types
00749         Flt80      f80;
00750         Flt80Parts f80Parts;
00751         Uns8       bytes[VMI_FP_80_BYTES];
00752     };
00753 } vmiFPArg;
00754 
00755 //
00756 // Union of a floating point value and its byte pattern
00757 //
00758 typedef union vmiFP80ArgU {
00759     Flt80      f80;
00760     Flt80Parts f80Parts;
00761     Uns8       bytes[VMI_FP_80_BYTES];
00762 } vmiFP80Arg;
00763 
00764 //
00765 // This function defines a 32-bit QNaN result callback, called when a native
00766 // floating point operation generates a 32-bit QNaN result. Arguments are:
00767 // 1. The processor.
00768 // 2. The 32-bit QNaN result from the operation.
00769 // 3. A count of the number of NaN arguments to the native operation.
00770 // 4. An ordered array of the NaN argument values.
00771 // 5. A count of the total number of arguments to the native operation.
00772 // 6. An ordered array of all argument values.
00773 // It should return a 32-bit QNaN result value result based on these arguments.
00774 //
00775 #define VMI_FP_QNAN32_RESULT_FN(_NAME) Uns32 _NAME( \
00776     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
00777     Uns32         QNaN32,       \
00778     Uns32         NaNArgNum,    \
00779     vmiFPArgP     NaNArgs,      \
00780     Uns32         allArgNum,    \
00781     vmiFPArgP     allArgs       \
00782 )
00783 typedef VMI_FP_QNAN32_RESULT_FN((*vmiFPQNaN32ResultFn));
00784 
00785 //
00786 // This function defines a 64-bit QNaN result callback, called when a native
00787 // floating point operation generates a 64-bit QNaN result. Arguments are:
00788 // 1. The processor.
00789 // 2. The 64-bit QNaN result from the operation.
00790 // 3. A count of the number of NaN arguments to the native operation.
00791 // 4. An ordered array of the NaN argument values.
00792 // 5. A count of the total number of arguments to the native operation.
00793 // 6. An ordered array of all argument values.
00794 // It should return a 64-bit QNaN result value result based on these arguments.
00795 //
00796 #define VMI_FP_QNAN64_RESULT_FN(_NAME) Uns64 _NAME( \
00797     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
00798     Uns64         QNaN64,       \
00799     Uns32         NaNArgNum,    \
00800     vmiFPArgP     NaNArgs,      \
00801     Uns32         allArgNum,    \
00802     vmiFPArgP     allArgs       \
00803 )
00804 typedef VMI_FP_QNAN64_RESULT_FN((*vmiFPQNaN64ResultFn));
00805 
00806 //
00807 // This function defines a 16-bit indeterminate result callback, called when a
00808 // native floating point operation generates a 16-bit indeterminate result (as
00809 // the result of a conversion operation). Argument 'value' holds the source
00810 // operand value for which conversion failed. The function should return an
00811 // Uns16 indeterminate result.
00812 //
00813 #define VMI_FP_IND16_RESULT_FN(_NAME) Uns16 _NAME( \
00814     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
00815     vmiFPArg      value,        \
00816     Bool          isSigned      \
00817 )
00818 typedef VMI_FP_IND16_RESULT_FN((*vmiFPInd16ResultFn));
00819 
00820 //
00821 // This function defines a 32-bit indeterminate result callback, called when a
00822 // native floating point operation generates a 32-bit indeterminate result (as
00823 // the result of a conversion operation). Argument 'value' holds the source
00824 // operand value for which conversion failed. The function should return an
00825 // Uns32 indeterminate result.
00826 //
00827 #define VMI_FP_IND32_RESULT_FN(_NAME) Uns32 _NAME( \
00828     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
00829     vmiFPArg      value,        \
00830     Bool          isSigned      \
00831 )
00832 typedef VMI_FP_IND32_RESULT_FN((*vmiFPInd32ResultFn));
00833 
00834 //
00835 // This function defines a 64-bit indeterminate result callback, called when a
00836 // native floating point operation generates a 64-bit indeterminate result (as
00837 // the result of a conversion operation). Argument 'value' holds the source
00838 // operand value for which conversion failed. The function should return an
00839 // Uns64 indeterminate result.
00840 //
00841 #define VMI_FP_IND64_RESULT_FN(_NAME) Uns64 _NAME( \
00842     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
00843     vmiFPArg      value,        \
00844     Bool          isSigned      \
00845 )
00846 typedef VMI_FP_IND64_RESULT_FN((*vmiFPInd64ResultFn));
00847 
00848 //
00849 // This function defines a tiny result handler. The argument and the return
00850 // value are unions holding the result value as an Flt80 type, Argument
00851 // 'isFlt32' is True if the required result is a 32-bit value and False if it
00852 // is a 64-bit value. Argument isIntermediate is True if the result is an
00853 // intermediate result in a multiply-add operation and False otherwise. Argument
00854 // 'setFlags' is a point to a flag structure which can be used to signal
00855 // additional flags raised as a result of handling the tiny result.
00856 //
00857 #define VMI_FP_TINY_RESULT_FN(_NAME) vmiFP80Arg _NAME( \
00858     vmiProcessorP processor,        \
00859     vmiFP80Arg    value,            \
00860     Bool          isFlt32,          \
00861     Bool          isIntermediate,   \
00862     vmiFPFlagsP   setFlags          \
00863 )
00864 typedef VMI_FP_TINY_RESULT_FN((*vmiFPTinyResultFn));
00865 
00866 //
00867 // This function defines a tiny argument handler. The argument and the return
00868 // value are unions holding the argument value as an Flt80 type.
00869 //
00870 #define VMI_FP_TINY_ARGUMENT_FN(_NAME) vmiFP80Arg _NAME( \
00871     vmiProcessorP processor,        \
00872     vmiFP80Arg    value,            \
00873     vmiFPFlagsP   setFlags          \
00874 )
00875 typedef VMI_FP_TINY_ARGUMENT_FN((*vmiFPTinyArgumentFn));
00876 
00877 //
00878 // This function defines a 32-bit general result callback, called after
00879 // execution of a floating point operation generating a 32-bit floating point
00880 // result. Arguments are:
00881 // 1. The processor.
00882 // 2. The operation result, as a 32-bit unsigned.
00883 // 3. A count of the number of arguments to the operation.
00884 // 4. An ordered array of all argument values.
00885 // 5. A flag structure which can be used to signal additional flags raised.
00886 // The function should return the final operation result and modify any flag
00887 // settings as required.
00888 //
00889 #define VMI_FP_32_RESULT_FN(_NAME) Uns32 _NAME( \
00890     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
00891     Uns32         result32,     \
00892     Uns32         argNum,       \
00893     vmiFPArgP     args,         \
00894     vmiFPFlagsP   setFlags      \
00895 )
00896 typedef VMI_FP_32_RESULT_FN((*vmiFP32ResultFn));
00897 
00898 //
00899 // This function defines a 64-bit general result callback, called after
00900 // execution of a floating point operation generating a 64-bit floating point
00901 // result. Arguments are:
00902 // 1. The processor.
00903 // 2. The operation result, as a 64-bit unsigned.
00904 // 3. A count of the number of arguments to the operation.
00905 // 4. An ordered array of all argument values.
00906 // 5. A flag structure which can be used to signal additional flags raised.
00907 // The function should return the final operation result and modify any flag
00908 // settings as required.
00909 //
00910 #define VMI_FP_64_RESULT_FN(_NAME) Uns64 _NAME( \
00911     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
00912     Uns64         result64,     \
00913     Uns32         argNum,       \
00914     vmiFPArgP     args,         \
00915     vmiFPFlagsP   setFlags      \
00916 )
00917 typedef VMI_FP_64_RESULT_FN((*vmiFP64ResultFn));
00918 
00919 //
00920 // Enumeration describing how a floating point exception was handled
00921 //
00922 typedef enum vmiFloatExceptionResultE {
00923     VMI_FLOAT_UNHANDLED,        // not handled
00924     VMI_FLOAT_CONTINUE,         // handled, continue execution
00925 } vmiFloatExceptionResult;
00926 
00927 //
00928 // Callback for floating point arithmetic exception handler
00929 // Return value indicates how the exception was handled
00930 //
00931 #define VMI_FP_ARITH_EXCEPT_FN(_NAME) vmiFloatExceptionResult _NAME( \
00932     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
00933     vmiFPFlagsP   flags         \
00934 )
00935 typedef VMI_FP_ARITH_EXCEPT_FN((*vmiFPArithExceptFn));
00936 
00937 //
00938 // This structure defines a floating point unit configuration. A configuration
00939 // may be specified globally using vmirtConfigureFPU, or per-instruction using
00940 // the final argument to VMI morph-time functions. If both a global
00941 // configuration and a per-instruction configuration are specified, the
00942 // per-instruction configuration takes precedence. Fields are as follows:
00943 //
00944 // QNaN32
00945 // ------
00946 // Default 32-bit QNaN (note that this defines the sense of the "quiet" bit in
00947 // 32-bit QNaN/SNaN values.
00948 //
00949 // QNaN64
00950 // ------
00951 // Default 64-bit QNaN (note that this defines the sense of the "quiet" bit in
00952 // 64-bit QNaN/SNaN values.
00953 //
00954 // indeterminateUns16
00955 // ------------------
00956 // Default 16-bit integer/unsigned indeterminate value. See also field
00957 // indeterminate16ResultCB.
00958 //
00959 // indeterminateUns32
00960 // ------------------
00961 // Default 32-bit integer/unsigned indeterminate value. See also field
00962 // indeterminate32ResultCB.
00963 //
00964 // indeterminateUns64
00965 // ------------------
00966 // Default 64-bit integer/unsigned indeterminate value. See also field
00967 // indeterminate64ResultCB.
00968 //
00969 // QNaN32ResultCB
00970 // --------------
00971 // If non-NULL, this function is called whenever a 32-bit QNaN result is
00972 // generated by a floating point operation. It gives the model the opportunity
00973 // to adjust the returned QNaN.
00974 //
00975 // QNaN64ResultCB
00976 // --------------
00977 // If non-NULL, this function is called whenever a 64-bit QNaN result is
00978 // generated by a floating point operation. It gives the model the opportunity
00979 // to adjust the returned QNaN.
00980 //
00981 // indeterminate16ResultCB
00982 // -----------------------
00983 // If non-NULL, this function is called whenever a 16-bit integer/unsigned
00984 // indeterminate result is generated by a floating point operation. It gives the
00985 // model the opportunity to adjust the returned value.
00986 //
00987 // indeterminate32ResultCB
00988 // -----------------------
00989 // If non-NULL, this function is called whenever a 32-bit integer/unsigned
00990 // indeterminate result is generated by a floating point operation. It gives the
00991 // model the opportunity to adjust the returned value.
00992 //
00993 // indeterminate64ResultCB
00994 // -----------------------
00995 // If non-NULL, this function is called whenever a 64-bit integer/unsigned
00996 // indeterminate result is generated by a floating point operation. It gives the
00997 // model the opportunity to adjust the returned value.
00998 //
00999 // tinyResultCB
01000 // ------------
01001 // If non-NULL, this function is called whenever a denormal result is generated
01002 // and flush-to-zero mode (FZ mode) is active. It gives the model the
01003 // opportunity to modify processor state when flush-to-zero occurs.
01004 //
01005 // tinyArgumentCB
01006 // --------------
01007 // If non-NULL, this function is called whenever a denormal argument is used
01008 // as input to a floating-point operation. It gives the model the opportunity to
01009 // modify processor state accordingly.
01010 //
01011 // fp32ResultCB
01012 // ------------
01013 // If non-NULL, this function is called whenever a 32-bit floating point result
01014 // is generated. It gives the model the opportunity to adjust the operation
01015 // result and any flags. This callback will normally be specified for
01016 // per-instruction configurations only.
01017 //
01018 // fp64ResultCB
01019 // ------------
01020 // If non-NULL, this function is called whenever a 64-bit floating point result
01021 // is generated. It gives the model the opportunity to adjust the operation
01022 // result and any flags. This callback will normally be specified for
01023 // per-instruction configurations only.
01024 //
01025 // fpArithExceptCB
01026 // ---------------
01027 // This specifies a floating-point exception handler function, called when
01028 // enabled exceptions are detected and before results are committed.
01029 //
01030 // suppressFlags
01031 // -------------
01032 // This specifies a mask of floating point flags that are suppressed by
01033 // operations using this configuration. Note that suppressing the Denormal
01034 // Operand flag improves floating point operation efficiency, especially for
01035 // SIMD operations.
01036 //
01037 // stickyFlags
01038 // -----------
01039 // This specifies whether flags generated by this operation are sticky. Sticky
01040 // flags are combined with existing floating point flags using bitwise-OR
01041 // without this having to be encoded specially in the model.
01042 //
01043 // fzClearsPF
01044 // ----------
01045 // This boolean specifies whether a flush-to-zero clears the precision flag.
01046 // By default, flush-to-zero sets the precision flag.
01047 //
01048 // tininessAfterRounding
01049 // ---------------------
01050 // This boolean specifies that detection of tiny numbers should be performed
01051 // after rounding (if True) or before rounding (if False).
01052 //
01053 typedef struct vmiFPConfigS {
01054     Uns32               QNaN32;
01055     Uns64               QNaN64;
01056     Uns16               indeterminateUns16;
01057     Uns32               indeterminateUns32;
01058     Uns64               indeterminateUns64;
01059     vmiFPQNaN32ResultFn QNaN32ResultCB;
01060     vmiFPQNaN64ResultFn QNaN64ResultCB;
01061     vmiFPInd16ResultFn  indeterminate16ResultCB;
01062     vmiFPInd32ResultFn  indeterminate32ResultCB;
01063     vmiFPInd64ResultFn  indeterminate64ResultCB;
01064     vmiFPTinyResultFn   tinyResultCB;
01065     vmiFPTinyArgumentFn tinyArgumentCB;
01066     vmiFP32ResultFn     fp32ResultCB;
01067     vmiFP64ResultFn     fp64ResultCB;
01068     vmiFPArithExceptFn  fpArithExceptCB;
01069     vmiFPFlags          suppressFlags;
01070     Bool                stickyFlags;
01071     Bool                fzClearsPF;
01072     Bool                tininessAfterRounding;
01073 } vmiFPConfig;
01074 
01075 //
01076 // This type defines a post-delay-slot function, called just before a delay slot
01077 // branch or jump is taken
01078 //
01079 #define VMI_POST_SLOT_FN(_NAME) void _NAME(vmiProcessorP processor)
01080 typedef VMI_POST_SLOT_FN((*vmiPostSlotFn));
01081 
01082 //
01083 // This type is used to define argument types for vmimtArgReg
01084 //
01085 typedef enum vmiRegArgTypeE {
01086 
01087     VPRRAT_8     =  8,              // 8-bit register argument
01088     VPRRAT_16    =  16,             // 16-bit register argument
01089     VPRRAT_32    =  32,             // 32-bit register argument
01090     VPRRAT_64    =  64,             // 64-bit register argument
01091 
01092     VPRRAT_FLT   = 0x80000000,      // floating-point argument identifier
01093     VPRRAT_FLT64 = 64|VPRRAT_FLT    // 64-bit floating point
01094 
01095 } vmiRegArgType;
01096 
01097 //
01098 // This type is used to define attributes of a called function
01099 //
01100 typedef enum vmiCallAttrsE {
01101     VMCA_NA     = 0x0,              // no attributes
01102     VMCA_PURE   = 0x1,              // this call is to a pure function
01103     VMCA_REPLAY = 0x2               // this call can be replayed if required
01104 } vmiCallAttrs;
01105 
01106 //
01107 // Callback function from morphed code
01108 //
01109 typedef void (*vmiCallFn)(void);
01110 
01111 //
01112 // Register description
01113 //
01114 typedef enum vmiRegTypeE {
01115     VRT_NOREG      = 0, // no register
01116     VRT_NORMAL     = 1, // normal register
01117     VRT_USEBASE    = 2, // no longer supported - do not use
01118     VRT_FUNCRESULT = 3  // register holding function result
01119 } vmiRegType;
01120 
01121 //
01122 // Register state
01123 //
01124 typedef enum vmiRegStateE {
01125     VRS_LIVE      = 0,  // register is live
01126     VRS_WRITEBACK = 1,  // register must be written back
01127     VRS_KILL      = 2   // register can be killed
01128 } vmiRegState;
01129 
01130 //
01131 // Processor register representation
01132 //
01133 typedef struct vmiRegS {
01134     IntPS index;
01135     struct {
01136         Bool        temp    : 1;
01137         Bool        address : 1;
01138         vmiRegType  type    : 2;
01139         vmiRegState state   : 2;
01140         vmiRegType  typeW   : 2;
01141         Bool        wb      : 1;
01142         Bool        address2: 1;
01143     } attrs;
01144 } vmiReg, *vmiRegP;
01145 
01146 //
01147 // Macro for filling vmiReg structure
01148 //
01149 #define VMI_REG_FILL(_INDEX, _TEMP, _ADDRESS, _TYPE, _TYPEW) { \
01150     index:_INDEX,           \
01151     attrs: {                \
01152         temp    : _TEMP,    \
01153         address : _ADDRESS, \
01154         type    : _TYPE,    \
01155         state   : 0,        \
01156         typeW   : _TYPEW,   \
01157         wb      : 0,        \
01158         address2: 0,        \
01159     }                       \
01160 }
01161 
01162 //
01163 // Get properties of vmiReg
01164 //
01165 #define VMI_REG_INDEX(_R)       ((_R).index)
01166 #define VMI_REG_ATTRS(_R)       ((_R).attrs)
01167 #define VMI_REG_TEMP(_R)        (VMI_REG_ATTRS(_R).temp)
01168 #define VMI_REG_ADDRESS(_R)     (VMI_REG_ATTRS(_R).address)
01169 #define VMI_REG_ADDRESS2(_R)    (VMI_REG_ATTRS(_R).address2)
01170 #define VMI_REG_TYPE(_R)        (VMI_REG_ATTRS(_R).type)
01171 #define VMI_REG_STATE(_R)       (VMI_REG_ATTRS(_R).state)
01172 #define VMI_REG_WB(_R)          (VMI_REG_ATTRS(_R).wb)
01173 
01174 //
01175 // Define for a normal register for VMI operations
01176 //
01177 #define VMI_REG_CONST(_I)       VMI_REG_FILL(_I, 0, 0, VRT_NORMAL, VRT_NOREG)
01178 #define VMI_REG(_I)             ((vmiReg)VMI_REG_CONST(_I))
01179 
01180 //
01181 // Define for an instruction-local temporary for VMI operations
01182 //
01183 #define VMI_TEMP_CONST(_I)      VMI_REG_FILL(_I, 1, 0, VRT_NORMAL, VRT_NOREG)
01184 #define VMI_TEMP(_I)            ((vmiReg)VMI_TEMP_CONST(_I))
01185 #define VMI_ISTEMP(_R)          VMI_REG_TEMP(_R)
01186 
01187 //
01188 // Define for no register for VMI operations
01189 //
01190 #define VMI_NOREG_CONST         VMI_REG_FILL(0, 0, 0, VRT_NOREG, VRT_NOREG)
01191 #define VMI_NOREG               ((vmiReg)VMI_NOREG_CONST)
01192 #define VMI_ISNOREG(_R)         (VMI_REG_TYPE(_R)!=VRT_NORMAL)
01193 
01194 //
01195 // Archaic mode - do not use
01196 //
01197 #define VMI_USEBASE_CONST       VMI_REG_FILL(0, 0, 0, VRT_USEBASE, VRT_NOREG)
01198 #define VMI_USEBASE             ((vmiReg)VMI_USEBASE_CONST)
01199 #define VMI_ISUSEBASE(_R)       (VMI_REG_TYPE(_R)==VRT_USEBASE)
01200 
01201 //
01202 // This register code can be used to indicate the result of the previous
01203 // embedded function call as the source argument of vmimtMoveRR
01204 //
01205 #define VMI_FUNCRESULT_CONST    VMI_REG_FILL(0, 0, 0, VRT_FUNCRESULT, VRT_NOREG)
01206 #define VMI_FUNCRESULT          ((vmiReg)VMI_FUNCRESULT_CONST)
01207 #define VMI_ISFUNCRESULT(_R)    (VMI_REG_TYPE(_R)==VRT_FUNCRESULT)
01208 
01209 //
01210 // Macros converting from field in CPU to equivalent vmiReg structure
01211 //
01212 #define VMI_CPU_OFFSET(_TP, _F) \
01213     ((IntPS)((UChar *)(&(((_TP)0)->_F))))
01214 #define VMI_CPU_REG(_TP, _F) \
01215     VMI_REG(VMI_CPU_OFFSET(_TP, _F))
01216 #define VMI_CPU_REG_CONST(_TP, _F) \
01217     VMI_REG_CONST(VMI_CPU_OFFSET(_TP, _F))
01218 #define VMI_CPU_TEMP(_TP, _F) \
01219     VMI_TEMP(VMI_CPU_OFFSET(_TP, _F))
01220 #define VMI_CPU_TEMP_CONST(_TP, _F) \
01221     VMI_TEMP_CONST(VMI_CPU_OFFSET(_TP, _F))
01222 
01223 //
01224 // Macros converting from field in CPU to equivalent vmiReg structure with a
01225 // further constant delta offset
01226 //
01227 #define VMI_CPU_OFFSET_DELTA(_TP, _F, _D) \
01228     ((IntPS)((UChar *)(&(((_TP)0)->_F)))+_D)
01229 #define VMI_CPU_REG_CONST_DELTA(_TP, _F, _D) \
01230     VMI_REG_CONST(VMI_CPU_OFFSET_DELTA(_TP, _F, _D))
01231 #define VMI_CPU_REG_DELTA(_TP, _F, _D) \
01232     VMI_REG(VMI_CPU_OFFSET_DELTA(_TP, _F, _D))
01233 
01234 //
01235 // Generate a new vmiReg using an offset from the passed one
01236 //
01237 #define VMI_REG_DELTA(_R, _D) ( \
01238     VMI_ISNOREG(_R) ?                   \
01239     (_R)            :                   \
01240     (vmiReg) {                          \
01241         index : VMI_REG_INDEX(_R)+_D,   \
01242         attrs : VMI_REG_ATTRS(_R)       \
01243     }                                   \
01244 )
01245 
01246 //
01247 // Are registers equal?
01248 //
01249 #define VMI_REG_EQUAL(_R1, _R2) ( \
01250     (VMI_REG_TYPE(_R1)==VMI_REG_TYPE(_R2)) && \
01251     (VMI_REG_INDEX(_R1)==VMI_REG_INDEX(_R2))  \
01252 )
01253 
01254 //
01255 // Flag identifiers for get & set of processor flags
01256 //
01257 typedef enum {
01258     vmi_CF=0,           // carry flag
01259     vmi_PF=1,           // parity flag
01260     vmi_ZF=2,           // zero flag
01261     vmi_SF=3,           // sign flag
01262     vmi_OF=4,           // overflow flag
01263     vmi_LF=5            // KEEP LAST
01264 } vmiFlag;
01265 
01266 //
01267 // Bitmask indicating whether particular flags should be negated
01268 //
01269 typedef enum {
01270     vmi_FN_NONE  =0x00, // empty negate mask
01271     vmi_FN_CF_IN =0x01, // negate carry in flag
01272     vmi_FN_CF_OUT=0x02, // negate carry out flag
01273     vmi_FN_PF    =0x04, // negate parity flag
01274     vmi_FN_ZF    =0x08, // negate zero flag
01275     vmi_FN_SF    =0x10, // negate sign flag
01276     vmi_FN_OF    =0x20, // negate overflow flag
01277 } vmiFlagNegate;
01278 
01279 //
01280 // Processor flag-related structures
01281 //
01282 typedef struct vmiFlagsS {
01283     vmiReg        cin;          // register specifying carry in
01284     vmiReg        f[vmi_LF];    // registers to hold operation results
01285     vmiFlagNegate negate;       // bitmask of negated flags
01286 } vmiFlags;
01287 
01288 //
01289 // Define for no no flags for VMI operations
01290 //
01291 #define VMI_NOFLAG       VMI_NOREG
01292 #define VMI_NOFLAG_CONST VMI_NOREG_CONST
01293 
01294 //
01295 // Empty flag set
01296 //
01297 #define VMI_NOFLAGS {                   \
01298     VMI_NOFLAG_CONST,                   \
01299     {                                   \
01300         [vmi_CF] = VMI_NOFLAG_CONST,    \
01301         [vmi_PF] = VMI_NOFLAG_CONST,    \
01302         [vmi_ZF] = VMI_NOFLAG_CONST,    \
01303         [vmi_SF] = VMI_NOFLAG_CONST,    \
01304         [vmi_OF] = VMI_NOFLAG_CONST     \
01305     },                                  \
01306     vmi_FN_NONE                         \
01307 }
01308 
01309 //
01310 // Callback function invoked by change of state on a net
01311 //
01312 #define VMI_NET_CHANGE_FN(_NAME) void _NAME( \
01313     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
01314     void         *userData,     \
01315     Uns32         newValue      \
01316 )
01317 typedef VMI_NET_CHANGE_FN((*vmiNetChangeFn));
01318 
01319 //
01320 // Callback function invoked by change of state on a connection object on which
01321 // this processor is blocked. This function should restart the processor using
01322 // vmirtRestartNow() or vmirtRestartNext() if required
01323 //
01324 #define VMI_CONN_UPDATE_FN(_NAME) void _NAME(vmiProcessorP processor)
01325 typedef VMI_CONN_UPDATE_FN((*vmiConnUpdateFn));
01326 
01327 //
01328 // This structure is filled with information about a connection object by
01329 // query functions
01330 //
01331 typedef struct vmiConnInfoS {
01332     Uns32 words;        // maximum number of entries the connection can hold
01333     Uns32 numFilled;    // number of filled entries
01334     Uns32 numEmpty;     // number of empty entries
01335     Uns32 bits;         // the width of each entry in bits
01336 } vmiConnInfo, *vmiConnInfoP;
01337

01341 typedef struct vmimmcPortS {

01343     vmimmcComponentP component;    // associated component
01344 } vmimmcPort;

01350     VMI_FETCH_NONE               = 0,
01351     VMI_FETCH_EXCEPTION_COMPLETE = 1,
01352     VMI_FETCH_EXCEPTION_PENDING  = 2
01353 } vmiFetchAction;

01360     VMI_LOAD_STORE_CONTINUE  = 1    // continue the current load/store
01361 } vmiLoadStoreAction;
01362 
01363 //

01365 // handler)

01367 typedef enum vmiIntegerExceptionTypeE {
01368     VMI_INTEGER_DIVIDE_BY_ZERO, // integer divide by zero
01369     VMI_INTEGER_OVERFLOW        // integer overflow
01370 } vmiIntegerExceptionType;
01371 
01372 //

01374 //

01376     VMI_INTEGER_UNHANDLED,      // not handled
01377     VMI_INTEGER_ABORT,          // handled, abort current instruction
01378     VMI_INTEGER_CONTINUE,       // handled, continue current instruction
01379 } vmiIntegerExceptionResult;
01380 
01381 //

01383 //

01386 #define VMI_NUMERIC_CONTINUE  VMI_INTEGER_CONTINUE
01387

01394 } vmiExceptionContext;

01409 //
01410 // Intercept notifier is called whenever an opaque function intercept is called
01411 // (even if the intercept is handled by a different intercept library) - useful
01412 // when writing analysis tools such as profilers which need to be aware of such
01413 // intercepts since they will be followed by an immediate "return".
01414 //
01415 #define VMIOS_INTERCEPT_NOTIFIER_FN(_NAME) void _NAME( \
01416     vmiProcessorP processor,    \
01417     vmiosObjectP  object,       \
01418     const char   *context,      \
01419     void         *userData      \
01420 )
01421 typedef VMIOS_INTERCEPT_NOTIFIER_FN((*vmiosInterceptNotifierFn));

01429     Int32  id,          \
01430     void  *userData     \
01431 )
01432 typedef VMI_SHARED_DATA_LISTENER_FN((*vmirtSharedDataListenerFn));

01434 //
01435 // Type of data returned by a vmiViewObject value callback
01436 // (N.B. Values must match PPM_VVT_xxx enum for PSEs)
01437 //
01438 typedef enum vmiViewValueTypeE {
01439     VMI_VVT_NOSPACE   = -1, // No value returned. More buffer required.
01440     VMI_VVT_ERROR     = 0,  // No value returned
01441 
01442     VMI_VVT_BOOL      = 1,  // Primitive types
01443     VMI_VVT_SCHAR     = 2,
01444     VMI_VVT_UCHAR     = 3,
01445     VMI_VVT_INT8      = 4,
01446     VMI_VVT_UNS8      = 5,
01447     VMI_VVT_INT16     = 6,
01448     VMI_VVT_UNS16     = 7,
01449     VMI_VVT_INT32     = 8,
01450     VMI_VVT_UNS32     = 9,
01451     VMI_VVT_INT64     = 10,
01452     VMI_VVT_UNS64     = 11,
01453     VMI_VVT_ADDR      = 12,
01454     VMI_VVT_FLT64     = 13,
01455 
01456     VMI_VVT_STRING    = 14,  // Single line string
01457     VMI_VVT_MULTILINE = 15,  // Multi line string
01458 
01459 } vmiViewValueType;
01460

01465 // more space,  e.g. multi-line string response, it returns the desired buffer
01466 // size and VMI_VVT_NOSPACE)
01467 //
01468 #define VMI_VIEW_VALUE_FN(_NAME) vmiViewValueType _NAME( \

01473 )

01555 //
01556 // This type specifies a block tag, used to implement conditional flushing of
01557 // code blocks - see functions vmimtTagBlock and vmirtFlushTargetModeTagged.
01558 //
01559 typedef enum vmiBlockTagE {
01560     VBT_NA = 0,         // no tag
01561     VBT_1  = (1<<0),    // tag 1
01562     VBT_2  = (1<<1),    // tag 2
01563     VBT_3  = (1<<2),    // tag 3
01564     VBT_4  = (1<<3),    // tag 4
01565     VBT_5  = (1<<4),    // tag 5
01566     VBT_6  = (1<<5),    // tag 6
01567     VBT_7  = (1<<6),    // tag 7
01568     VBT_8  = (1<<7),    // tag 8
01569 } vmiBlockTag;
